Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South2nd FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2596special.collections@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2019-11-26T15:04:10EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content StandardNovember 2019
Edited by Amy Lau to reflect the processing of 2015.004, 2015.055, 2015.059 accessions.
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Pauline Park Papers
Park, Pauline
Park, Pauline
TAM.663
7.25 Linear Feet in 16 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 1 oversize flat box, and 1 oversize folder in shared housing.
3 videocassettes (vhs)
10 audiocassettes
951 Megabytes in 92 computer files.
1986-2015, undated 2000-2015 The Pauline Park Papers contains material from 1986-2015 documenting the advocacy, activism, and writing of Pauline Park, a transgender activist, speaker, writer, and educator. A large portion of the collection contains material from the New York Association for Gender Rights Advocacy (NYAGRA) and Queens Pride House (QPH) two organizations that Park helped co-found, in 1998 and 1997, respectively, and lead. Park campaigned for the transgender rights law enacted by the New York City Council in 2002, and in 2005 became the first openly transgender grand marshal of the New York City Pride March. Park has been the keynote speaker at many LGBT and Asian American conferences and events held in the United States. She has written extensively about arts and culture, music, spirituality, politics, theatre, race, and LGBT health and rights. Her writing has been published in journals, newspapers, and newsletters. This collection contains materials on subjects such as transgender health, identity, community, and public policy, and includes correspondence, board meeting minutes, photographs, VHS tapes, conference name badges, certificates, audio recordings, original poetry and creative writing, notes, speeches, flyers and programs for events and conferences related to QPH and NYAGRA, press featuring Park, and letters to politicians and allied organizations advocating the passage of LGTBQ inclusion and non-discrimination legislation. The majority of materials are in English, with a limited number of materials in Korean.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
Donated by Pauline Park in 2015. The accession numbers associated with these gifts are 2015.004, 2015.055, and 2015.059.
Arrangement
This collection is arranged into four series. The collection is arranged into groupings by subject matter that reflect the original order in which the collection was donated to the Tamiment Library. The arrangement is as follows:
I. Organizations, 1986-2015, undated
II. Writings, Publications, and Other Related Creative Projects, 1989-2015, undated
III. Events, 1990-2014, undated
IV. Personal, 1994-2015, undated
Historical/Biographical Note
Pauline Park (1960- ) is a transgender activist based in New York City who received her PhD in Political Science from the University of Illinois. Park was born in Korea, and was adoped and raised by European American parents. As of 2019, she is the President of the Board of Directors and Acting Executive Director of Queens Pride House (QPH) and Chair of the New York Association for Gender Rights Advocacy (NYAGRA). Park led the campaign for the transgender rights law enacted by the New York City Council in 2002, and in 2005 became the first openly transgender grand marshal of the New York City Pride March. Pauline has written widely on LGBTQ issues and has conducted transgender sensitivity training sessions for a wide range of organizations. She was the subject of the 2008 documentary Envisioning Justice: The Journey of a Transgendered Woman. Park was named to Huffington Post's list of "The Most Influential LGBT Asian Icons" and to a list of "50 Transgender Icons" on the Transgender Day of Remembrance in 2012.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Pauline Park Papers; TAM 663; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information Note
At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused into new acid-free folders and boxes, with original folder titles transcribed. The original order of the collection as maintained by Pauline Park has been retained, with the exception of audiovisual and oversize items which were removed and rehoused in appropriate size boxes. Box-level descriptions were created by an archivist based on the contents of each box.
At the time of processing, all materials in six record cartons were rehoused into manuscript boxes due to overfilling and box tearing. Rehousing materials from the six record cartons caused the number of boxes to expand from 8 to 18. During processing folders were scored and marked with the collection call number, box number, and folder number; most of the original folder titles were retained, although there were some descriptive enhancements. A number of newspaper clippings intermixed within all of the series which were photocopied onto preservation paper for conservation purposes.
Born-digital material was imaged and labeled. One optical disc was processed using Forensic Toolkit, and an audio disc was imaged and uploaded to permanent storage. One floppy disc was imaged and the file was uploaded to permanent storage.
New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.
Scope and Content Note
This collection contains materials related to the advocacy, activism, and writing of Pauline Park from 1986 to 2015. The bulk of the material in this collection comes from the early 1990s to the mid 2010s, and documents Park's work as co-founder and co-leader of the New York Association for Gender Rights Advocacy, the first New York statewide transgender advocacy organization, and Queens Pride House, the LGBT community center of Queens, New York. The collection contains some of Park's published and unpublished writing which addresses topics of transgender health, identity, community, and public policy as well as race, national identity, philosophy, spirituality, and the arts. Materials in the collection include correspondence, programs, digital images, photographs, VHS and audio cassette tapes, conference name badges, certificates, audio recordings, original poetry and creative writing, flyers for events and conferences related to Queens Pride House (QPH) and the New York Association for Gender Rights Advocacy (NYAGRA) and other organizations. There are a number of press clippings and magazine articles featuring Park as well as letters to politicians, and allied organizations advocating the passage of LGTBQ non-discrimination legislation. The collection also contains a number of documentaries about or featuring Park and a sound recording of Park preforming classical piano music. Park donated the proceeds of the sound recording to NYAGRA and QPH.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact special.collections@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Conditions Governing Use
This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Custodial History
These materials were solicited by Laura Chen Schulz Deputy Director of New York University's Asian/Pacific/American Institute and Tim Naftali, Tamiment Director and shipped direct to Tamiment by Pauline Park. Initially, five boxes were donated to Tamiment on January 25, 2015 which comprised the 2015.004 accession. The rest of the boxes were received from Pauline Park on unknown dates in 2015.
Electronic Records Policies and Procedures
Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

Asian Americans -- Political activity Asian American sexual minorities. Gender identity -- United States Gender, sexuality & culture New York Association for Gender Rights Advocacy Park, Pauline
Series I. Organizations2 Linear Feetin 5 manuscript boxes.106 kilobytesin 1 computer file.5 audiocassettes1986-2015, undated
Arrangement
This series is grouped by organization, then arranged alphabetically by title.
Scope and Contents
Material in this series largely contains material from Pauline Park's work with the New York Association for Gender Rights Advocacy (NYAGRA) and Queens Pride House from the 1900s to the mid 2010s. Most the materials in this series documents Park's work applying to various grants, speaking at various events,and writing letters regarding New York State's Dignity for All Students Act on behalf of NYAGRA. There are some material from other LGBT and Asian American organizations as well. Material in this series includes: board meeting minutes, audio recordings, notes, correspondence between Park and NYAGRA/QPH members, certificates of incorporation, grant proposals and reports, flyers, press, testimony, information packets, and brochures.
There is some born-digital media--one Word document--in this series. Writings, Publications, and Other Related Creative Projects2 Linear Feetin 4.5 manuscript boxes.669 Megabytesin 2 computer files.1989-2015, undated
Arrangement
This series is grouped by title, then arranged in alphabetical order.
Scope and Contents
This series contains published and unpublished creative, critical, academic, and personal written material by Park from the late 1990s to the mid 2010s. The material in this series includes drafts of personal essays, articles published in LGBT magazines, VHS tapes, published letters to newspaper editors, book chapters, poetry, a play script, and an audio recording of Park playing the piano.

Events2 Linear Feetin 4.5 manuscript boxes, and 1 oversize folder in shared housing.282 Megabytesin 89 computer files.2 audiocassettes1990-2014, undated
Arrangement
Material in this series is grouped by file title, then arranged in chronological order.
Scope and Contents
This series contains ephemera from the many events where Park was a speaker, panelist moderator, participant, or attendee. The bulk of the material from this series comes from 1997-2014. Of note in this series are flyers, programs, and press from 2005 when Park was the first openly transgender marshall in the New York City Pride March and name badges from events that Park participated in. There is a sound recording on two audiocassettes of an interview with Lee Chung-Woo (Chingusai-Seoul). Ephemera from this series include: flyers, programs, brochures, speaking contracts, speeches, digital images, photographs, testimony from court cases, correspondence, and legal notices from court cases.

Arrangement
This series is grouped by file title, then arranged in alphabetical order.
Scope and Contents
This series mostly contains material about Pauline Park's life that was created by other writers or artists. While most of the material comes from press about Park, there are also a significant number of interviews with, and documentaries about, Pauline Park. Material in this series includes: VHS tapes, audiocassette recordings of interviews with Park, written interviews with Park, publications, correspondence, award plaques with related program, and press.1994 Press Coverage1 folder199410121997 Press Coverage1 folder199710131999 Press Coverage1 folder199910142000 Press Coverage1 folder20001112001 Press Coverage1 folder20011122002 Press Coverage1 folder20021132003 Press Coverage1 folder20031142004 Press Coverage1 folder20041152005 Press Coverage1 folder20051162006 Press Coverage1 folder20061172007 Press Coverage1 folder20071182008 Press Coverage1 folder20081192009 Press Coverage1 folder200911102010 Press Coverage1 folder201011112011 Press Coverage1 folder20111112Academic Articles on Homosexuality and Islam1 folderundated1612Activities and Correspondence1 folder1998-2015, undated185Award Plaques: Transworld III Conference and Translatina Community5916021 box2001-20027Award and Special Recognition1 folder2002-2006187Correspondence2 folders2012-2015, undated14101711Correspondence: Nasser, Sana1 folder20061611Embodying Asian/American Sexualities Interview1 folder2004-20051417Interviews2 folders2005-2006123, 4Letters to Pauline Park1 folder20051510Press: "The Glass is Half Full, Mostly" (Park Quoted)1 folder2003174Press Clippings1 folder2005-2015147Program: "Who is Pauline Park?"
